segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 22
segments.en: Linked Discourses 22

segments.pli: 8. Khajjanīyavagga
segments.en: 8. Itchy

segments.pli: 80. Piṇḍolyasutta
segments.en: 80. Beggars

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kismiñcideva pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇāmetvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kapilavatthuṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha, having dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha for some reason, robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.

segments.pli: Kapilavatthusmiṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena mahāvanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
segments.en: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Great Wood,

segments.pli: Mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā beluvalaṭṭhikāya mūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood apple tree for the day’s meditation.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
segments.en: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

segments.pli: “mayā kho bhikkhusaṅgho pabāḷho.
segments.en: “I’ve sent the mendicant Saṅgha away.

segments.pli: Santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ.
segments.en: But there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.

segments.pli: Tesaṃ mamaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
segments.en: Not seeing me they may change and fall apart.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṃ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
segments.en: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart. …

segments.pli: evameva santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ tesaṃ mamaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
Seyyathāpi nāma bījānaṃ taruṇānaṃ udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
segments.en: Or if young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart.

segments.pli: evameva santettha … pe …
segments.en: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.

segments.pli: tesaṃ mamaṃ alabhantānaṃ dassanāya siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
segments.en: Not seeing me they may change and fall apart.

segments.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yatheva mayā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito, evameva etarahi anuggaṇheyyaṃ bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.
segments.en: Why don’t I support the mendicant Saṅgha now as I did in the past?”

segments.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
segments.en: Then Brahmā Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the Brahmā realm and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

segments.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

segments.pli: “evametaṃ, bhagavā, evametaṃ, sugata.
segments.en: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

segments.pli: Bhagavatā, bhante, bhikkhusaṃgho pabāḷho.
segments.en: The Buddha has sent the mendicant Saṅgha away.

segments.pli: Santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ.
segments.en: But there are mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. …

segments.pli: Tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
Seyyathāpi nāma vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṃ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
evameva santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
Seyyathāpi nāma bījānaṃ taruṇānaṃ udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
evameva santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ alabhantānaṃ dassanāya siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
Abhinandatu, bhante, bhagavā bhikkhusaṃghaṃ;
segments.en: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!

segments.pli: abhivadatu, bhante, bhagavā bhikkhusaṃghaṃ.
segments.en: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!

segments.pli: Yatheva bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṃgho anuggahito, evameva etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṃghan”ti.
segments.en: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”

segments.pli: Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
segments.en: The Buddha consented in silence.

segments.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
segments.en: Then Brahmā Sahampati, knowing that the Buddha had consented, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena nigrodhārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the Banyan Tree Monastery, where he sat on the seat spread out.

segments.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā te bhikkhū ekadvīhikāya sārajjamānarūpā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkameyyuṃ.
segments.en: Then he used his psychic power to will that the mendicants would come to him timidly, alone or in pairs.

segments.pli: Tepi bhikkhū ekadvīhikāya sārajjamānarūpā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: Those mendicants approached the Buddha timidly, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

segments.pli: “Antamidaṃ, bhikkhave, jīvikānaṃ yadidaṃ piṇḍolyaṃ.
segments.en: “Mendicants, this relying on alms is an extreme way to live.

segments.pli: Abhisāpoyaṃ, bhikkhave, lokasmiṃ piṇḍolo vicarasi pattapāṇīti.
segments.en: The world curses you: ‘You beggar, walking bowl in hand!’

segments.pli: Tañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputtā upenti atthavasikā, atthavasaṃ paṭicca;
segments.en: Yet earnest and gentlemen take it up for a good reason.

segments.pli: neva rājābhinītā, na corābhinītā, na iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā, na ājīvikāpakatā;
segments.en: Not because they’ve been forced to by kings or bandits, or because they’re in debt or threatened, or to earn a living.

segments.pli: api ca kho otiṇṇāmha jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇā dukkhaparetā
segments.en: But because they’re swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

segments.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
segments.en: And they think, ‘Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ pabbajito cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputto.
segments.en: That’s how this gentleman has gone forth.

segments.pli: So ca hoti abhijjhālu kāmesu tibbasārāgo byāpannacitto paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo.
segments.en: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and hateful intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, chavālātaṃ ubhatopadittaṃ majjhe gūthagataṃ, neva gāme kaṭṭhatthaṃ pharati, nāraññe kaṭṭhatthaṃ pharati.
segments.en: Suppose there was a firebrand for lighting a funeral pyre, burning at both ends, and smeared with dung in the middle. It couldn’t be used as timber either in the village or the wilderness.

segments.pli: Tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi gihibhogā ca parihīno, sāmaññatthañca na paripūreti.
segments.en: I say that person is just like this. They’ve missed out on the pleasures of the lay life, and haven’t fulfilled the goal of the ascetic life.

segments.pli: Tayome, bhikkhave, akusalavitakkā—
segments.en: There are these three unskillful thoughts.

segments.pli: kāmavitakko, byāpādavitakko, vihiṃsāvitakko.
segments.en: Sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts.

segments.pli: Ime ca bhikkhave, tayo akusalavitakkā kva aparisesā nirujjhanti?
segments.en: And where do these three unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over?

segments.pli: Catūsu vā satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittassa viharato animittaṃ vā samādhiṃ bhāvayato.
segments.en: In those who meditate with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; or who develop signless immersion.

segments.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva animitto samādhi bhāvetuṃ.
segments.en: Just this much is quite enough motivation to develop signless immersion.

segments.pli: Animitto, bhikkhave, samādhi bhāvito bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso.
segments.en: When signless immersion is developed and cultivated it is very fruitful and beneficial.

segments.pli: Dvemā, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiyo—
segments.en: There are these two views.

segments.pli: bhavadiṭṭhi ca vibhavadiṭṭhi ca.
segments.en: Views favoring continued existence and views favoring ending existence.

segments.pli: Tatra kho, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
segments.en: A noble disciple reflects on this:

segments.pli: ‘atthi nu kho taṃ kiñci lokasmiṃ yamahaṃ upādiyamāno na vajjavā assan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Is there anything in the world that I could grasp without fault?’

segments.pli: So evaṃ pajānāti:
segments.en: They understand:

segments.pli: ‘natthi nu kho taṃ kiñci lokasmiṃ yamahaṃ upādiyamāno na vajjavā assaṃ.
segments.en: ‘There’s nothing in the world that I could grasp without fault.

segments.pli: Ahañhi rūpaññeva upādiyamāno upādiyeyyaṃ vedanaññeva …
segments.en: For in grasping I would grasp only at form, feeling,

segments.pli: saññaññeva …
segments.en: perception,

segments.pli: saṅkhāreyeva viññāṇaññeva upādiyamāno upādiyeyyaṃ.
segments.en: choices, or consciousness.

segments.pli: Tassa me assa upādānapaccayā bhavo;
segments.en: That grasping of mine would be a condition for continued existence.

segments.pli: bhavapaccayā jāti;
segments.en: Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.

segments.pli: jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhaveyyuṃ.
segments.en: Rebirth is a condition that gives rise to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

segments.pli: Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo assā’ti.
segments.en: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

segments.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave,
segments.en: What do you think, mendicants?

segments.pli: rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: Is form permanent or impermanent?”

segments.pli: “Aniccaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

segments.pli: “Dukkhaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

segments.pli: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Vedanā …
segments.en: “Is feeling …

segments.pli: saññā …
segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: saṅkhārā …
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ … pe …
segments.en: consciousness permanent or impermanent?” …

segments.pli: tasmātiha, bhikkhave,
segments.en: “So you should truly see …

segments.pli: evaṃ passaṃ …
segments.en: Seeing this …

segments.pli: nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”

segments.pli: Aṭṭhamaṃ.

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying in the…

suttaplex.blurb: While staying at Kapilavatthu the Buddha dismissed the the Sangha for misbehaving. Later he decided to support them for the sake of the young mendicants. He reminds them that their livelihood is considered a lowly one, and that one should let go of bad thoughts and wrong views, and see the aggregates as impermanent.
